overview: From 2025-10-01 to 2025-11-01, Sendo-labs/spotlight had 1 new PRs (0 merged), 0 new issues, and 2 active contributors.

topPRs.title: Complete SOL transfer logic and unit tests
topPRs.author: 0domart
topPRs.body:
This PR includes:

- Fixed SOL transfer logic using proper CPI for user→vault transfers and direct lamport manipulation for vault→recipients
- Added admin verification (only the creator can settle auctions)
- Added time validation (auctions must end before settling)
- Implemented comprehensive unit tests
- Updated README with quick start instructions
- All tests passing ✅

Key changes:
- Replaced problematic `try_borrow_mut_lamports()` with proper Anchor CPI patterns
- Added `admin` field to `SpotState` for proper access control
- Fixed account space calculations
- Added proper error handling and validation

topContributors.summary: Neysixx: This month, Neysixx led a foundational overhaul of the `Sendo-labs/frontend` repository, merging six pull requests focused on restructuring and feature development. Their most impactful contribution was a massive project-wide refactor to update the structure and configurations (Sendo-labs/frontend#1), which involved over 34,000 line changes. In addition, they implemented new pages (Sendo-labs/frontend#7), improved the page structure (Sendo-labs/frontend#3), and resolved a critical build issue by adding missing dependencies (Sendo-labs/frontend#5). This work demonstrates a clear focus on large-scale refactoring and feature implementation within the frontend codebase.

standujar: Focused on bootstrapping several new projects and plugins this month, merging multiple foundational pull requests. They established the initial implementation for the CryptoScore plugin (Sendo-labs/plugin-cryptoscore#1), the frontend project (Sendo-labs/frontend#2), and the Sendo Worker (Sendo-labs/plugin-sendo-worker#1). The Sendo Worker PR was particularly significant, introducing over 13,000 lines of code to establish the new service. This activity shows a primary focus on new feature work and initial project configuration.

xdrkush: Focused on establishing the new `Sendo-labs/sendo-api` repository, merging two pull requests. Their most significant contribution was the initial commit of the project (PR #1), which introduced over 21,000 lines of code. They also resolved a bug related to the buy/sell account functionality in PR #3, demonstrating a focus on both foundational work and bug fixes.

M4XGO focused on establishing and improving development infrastructure this month by creating a foundational set of reusable workflows and release management processes in Sendo-labs/reusable-workflows#1, a significant effort involving over 1000 lines of new code. They then applied this new system to enable automated release management and NPM publishing for the plugin-cryptoscore repository (Sendo-labs/plugin-cryptoscore#2). This work was concentrated entirely on configuration and documentation files, reflecting a clear focus on developer tooling and automation.

0xCanet: This month, 0xCanet's work was centered on the foundational setup of the new `Sendo-labs/frontend` repository. They merged a single, substantial pull request (Sendo-labs/frontend#1), which introduced the initial codebase for the project. This commit added over 9,200 lines of code across 111 files, establishing the new frontend application.

0domart: This month, 0domart focused on developing new functionality in the Sendo-labs/spotlight repository. They opened a significant pull request (#1) to implement SOL transfer logic and its corresponding unit tests. This work-in-progress involved a substantial effort, with over 1500 new lines of code added across 12 files, indicating a primary focus on building out test suites.

tionebDotsamapha: Focused on improving project documentation this month, merging a pull request (#2) to update the README file to English in the Sendo-labs/sendo-api repository. This contribution represented their sole activity, with all changes concentrated on documentation.
